text:
A series of devastating earthquakes has killed 
at least 1,300 people in Turkey and Syria, and

thousands of people are evacuating in eastern Ohio 
because of a fiery train derailment. Good morning,

I'm Korva Coleman, from NPR News, and here are 
today's top stories. A catastrophic earthquake

with a magnitude of 7.8 hit southern Turkey and 
northern Syria overnight. It has been followed by

aftershocks — one almost as powerful as the main 
tremor. More than 1,300 people have been killed in

both countries. The death toll continues to soar. 
NPR's Ruth Sherlock says that is because the reach

of the quakes' damage in Turkey is colossal. "So 
the epicenter of this earthquake was just north of

Gaziantep — that's a provincial capital in Turkey 
with a population of about 2 million people — and

the earthquake was so strong that there are 
reports of buildings collapsed in an area that

spans 200 miles around the epicenter." NPR's Ruth 
Sherlock reporting. The tremors have been felt as

far away as Lebanon and even the the island of 
Cyprus, in the eastern Mediterranean Sea. Making

matters worse is that there is a snowstorm in the 
area — people forced out of their homes may have

no shelter. Standing mosques have opened to take 
people in. More fierce fighting is reported in the

eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut, where Ukrainian 
forces have been holding out against a Russian

offensive. From Moscow, NPR's Charles Maynes has 
details. "The head of the Russian mercenary force

the Wagner Group, Yevgeny Prigozhin, said battles 
were going on for every street, every house and

every stairwell in Bakhmut, a city that Russia 
sees as central to efforts to re-establish control

over Ukraine's wider Donbas region. Russian 
armed forces backed by Wagner fighters — many of

them convicts — have been attempting to encircle 
Bakhmut for weeks. Both Kyiv and Moscow claim the

other has suffered significant losses in the fight 
for the city. Outside observers point to evidence

Russia now has the upper hand. Yet Ukrainian 
President Volodymyr Zelensky has vowed to defend

the city, whose survival has become a cause 
célèbre in Ukraine. Charles Maynes, NPR News,

Moscow. In the U.S., some limited evacuations are 
taking place in eastern Ohio — that's because of

a fiery freight train derailment. As NPR's Marie 
Andrusewicz reports, the freight rail train left

the tracks last Friday. "Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine 
issued an evacuation notice for residents within

a mile of the site of a still-burning 50-car 
train derailment. This comes after officials

reported a drastic temperature change in one of 
the cars that could lead to a major explosion.

East Palestine Fire Chief Keith Drabick: 'This 
catastrophic failure will, if it, if it occurs,

it will produce hydrogen chloride and phosgene 
gas into the atmosphere. We are working with

several federal agencies to determine a plume 
cloud for that.' Safety teams are working to

prevent the explosion that officials say would 
project deadly shrapnel as far as a mile. Law

enforcement officers are trying to evacuate 
any residents that remain. Meanwhile Gov.

DeWine has activated the National Guard. 
Marie Andrusewicz, NPR News." This is NPR.
